definition:
1. To fly aloft, as a bird; to mount upward on wings, or as on wings. Chaucer. When soars Gaul's vulture with his wings unfurled. Byron. 2. Fig.: To rise in thought, spirits, or imagination; to be exalted in mood. Where the deep transported mind may soar. Milton. Valor soars above What the world calls misfortune. Addison.

The act of soaring; upward flight. This apparent soar of the hooded falcon. Coleridge.

See 3d Sore. [Obs.]

See Sore, reddish brown. Soar falcon. (Zo√∂l.) See Sore falcon, under Sore.
